tossups.question: In a 2010 history titled for the “empire” of these things, J.R. McNeill claims that they were responsible for both American success at Yorktown and a large share of racial intermixing in the New World, since events brought about by these things caused soldiers to seek out African or Creole wives. A people whose name is the phonetic equivalent of these things had impoverished kings who took names like Jeremy and George Frederic Augustus, who Scottish conman Gregor MacGregor claimed awarded him the fabricated territory of (*) “Poyais,” which was supposedly located in a region known by this name. These things were at the center of Operation Drop Kick, carried out in Savannah, Georgia. Carlos Finlay noted that the sugar industry created a boon for these animals, as it required deforestation that removed many of their natural predators. Clara Maass and Jesse William Lazear died while confirming a hypothesis about these animals, which enabled a 1904-1914 project that succeeded where Ferdinand de Lesseps had failed. Walter Reed found that yellow fever was transmitted by—for 10 points—what insect?
tossups.answer: mosquitoes [prompt on disease or yellow fever or malaria; accept Aedes or Anopheles] <History - Other/World>

tossups.question: In 2009, one type of these drugs received a black box warning due to risk of gangrene via subcutaneous injection or IV push. One of these drugs which only has action against the second isotype of their namesake receptor is also a potent anti-androgen; that drug causes a reduction in the transmembrane levels of an H+/K+ ATP-ase. Their first-generation types block both the central and peripheral receptors of their namesake neurotransmitter, while their second-generation types include (*) feno·fexadine, ce·tiri·zine, and loratadine. These drugs counter the action of a cell type that is activated by complement activation byproducts or cross-linking of surface I·g·E receptors. Diphenhydramine is one of these drugs, which promote dilation of bronchial smooth muscle and vasoconstriction of post-capillary venules, treating breathing issues and hives. The chemical product of mast cells is opposed by—for 10 points—what class of drugs, of which Benadryl is a member?
tossups.answer: antihistamines [or histamine receptor antagonists; accept H1 or H2 antagonists until…?; anti-prompt on any specific antihistamines, like promethazine, chlorpheniramine, diphenhydramine, Benadryl, fenofexadine, cetirizine, or loratadine] <Science - Biology>

tossups.question: Due to his weeping, one character compares this man to a “silly girl” who “catches hold of her mother’s dress” and “looks up tearfully until she picks her up.” Homer’s account of the Trojan attack on the Greek ships is bookended by two scenes in which this man tends to Eurypylus’ arrow-wound. In the Iliad, this man’s dream-ghost asks for his ashes to be held in a golden urn; he also recalls leaving Opus after killing a son of Amphidamas, who is known through other sources to be named (*) Clitonymus. A blow from Apollo enables Euphorbus to wound this man with a spear. This man kills a son of Zeus whose death is portended by a shower of blood; that son of Zeus is Sarpedon. The majority of Book 23 of the Iliad describes the funeral games of this man, who is killed by Hector while wearing another hero’s armor. For 10 points, name this man, whose death brings his companion Achilles back to the battlefield in the Iliad.
tossups.answer: Patroclus [or Patroklos] <Mythology and Other>

tossups.question: In the first of these pieces, the first movement’s primary theme pauses on scale-degree 2, with almost the entire consequent phrase played over a G pedal. That theme is played in the bass, causing the first of these pieces to start on a rootless 6-4 chord. The last of these pieces begins with a long F-sharp diminished-seventh chord, followed by an F dominant-seventh chord, despite being in C major. The first of these pieces has a trio-less scherzo that begins with the cello alone playing repeated B-flats in the rhythm: “short-short long, long; short-short long, long….” These pieces were published five years after their composer’s Opus (*) 18 in the same genre. The theme of the trio from the second piece in this set can be heard in the opening scene of Boris Godunov. Two of these three pieces have sections headed “Thème Russe.” The “Harp” and “Serioso” quartets are often grouped with—for 10 points—what set of string quartets that Beethoven wrote for a Russian count?
tossups.answer: Razumovsky Quartets [or Beethoven’s Opus 59; or Beethoven’s String Quartets 7, 8, and 9; prompt on answers like Beethoven’s string quartets] <Arts - Auditory>

tossups.question: This author’s first play flopped because it was overshadowed by Hugh Kelly’s awful comedy False Delicacy. Audiences hissed during the “low” scene of that play by this author, in which Miss Richland discovers two bailiffs accosting Honeywood. An essay by this author unfavorably compares the “bastard tragedy” of sentimental comedy with “laughing comedy.” This author’s final play includes a comic scene in which a man prevents an unwanted marriage by driving his mother around a house in circles before dumping her in a (*) horsepond. In a play by this author, the song “Let schoolmasters puzzle their brain / With grammar, and nonsense, and learning” is sung by Tony, who then pranks the protagonist by directing him to a local house and telling him it’s an inn. That prank causes the normally shy Marlow to court a maid who turns out to be Kate Hardcastle. For 10 points, name this eighteenth-century British author of the comedies The Good Natur’d Man and She Stoops to Conquer.
tossups.answer: Oliver Goldsmith <Literature - British>

tossups.question: For a thin-film capillary flow down an incline with a free upper surface, the height of the thin-film raised to this power is proportional to the volume of fluid flow per unit time. Classical GR in this number of total dimensions only allows flat solutions to the vacuum Einstein field equations. For a photon gas, the internal energy is equal to “this number, times pressure, times volume.” This whole number of dimensions is the only case in which the (*) critical exponents of the classical Ising model are not analytically known. In special relativity, the force on an object parallel to the direction of motion is equal to “mass, times acceleration, times the Lorentz factor raised to this power.” Feynman diagrams in QED have vertices with this degree. For any closed Newtonian orbit, the period squared is proportional to the semi-major axis length raised to this power. For 10 points, give this number of translational degrees of freedom for a monatomic gas particle.
tossups.answer: 3 <Science - Physics>

tossups.question: A member of this house rescued his cousin, John V Paleologus, from Bulgar captivity after diverting its namesake crusade against Murad I. This house was founded by a Burgundian soldier named Humbert White-hand, and included a general whose victory at Saint Quentin forced France to sign the Treaty of Cateau-Cambresis. Emmanuel Philibert of this house ordered a notable 1655 massacre of Waldensians commemorated in a (*) sonnet by John Milton. A penchant for monochromatic armor earned another member of this house the nickname “the Green Count.” This dynasty's defection from Louis XIV was a major turning point in the War of the Spanish Succession. That move by Victor Amadeus allowed this house to acquire an island to the south of its continental holdings, creating a kingdom that became the basis for modern Italy. For 10 points, name this house that ruled the kingdom of Piedmont-Sardinia and produced the Prince Eugene.
tossups.answer: House of Savoy [or casa Savoia; or maison de Savoie] <History - European>

tossups.question: A chapter of a novel describing the political economy of this place was inspired by the contemporary theory of the “Circulus.” That chapter calls this place a “mistake” that yearly sweeps “twenty-five millions” into “the abyss.” A chapter about this place’s “ancient history” calls it “the conscience of the city” because everything here “converges and confronts everything else” in its “true form.” The description of this place’s details was informed by the author’s friend (*) Bruneseau, who officially explored it. This place’s wastefulness is attacked in a section of a novel comparing it to the intestine of Leviathan. Before unlocking the gate allowing the protagonist to escape this place, Thenardier sneakily tears a strip off of Marius’s coat. For 10 points, Jean Valjean carries an unconscious Marius through what location underneath Paris in Book Five of Les Miserables?
tossups.answer: Paris sewers [or les égouts de Paris] <Literature - European>

tossups.question: Sino-Japanese tensions rose after Japan secured a contract to build the Matarbari deep water port in this country, leading to the cancellation of a similar project at Sonadia. A humanitarian campaign to build tube wells in this country disastrously resulted in what the W.H.O. called “the largest mass poisoning in history,” as the wells were accidentally dug exactly to the depth of massive arsenic deposits. China stepped in after European companies refused to fund this country’s environmentally devastating Rampal coal plant and hyper-corrupt (*) bridge project, helping to make this country the second-largest recipient of Belt and Road funding. A horrifying murder in this country was caught on video after members of the BCL mistook a tailor for a supporter of its 18-Party Alliance. The controversial Padma Bridge is in this country, whose recent politics have been dominated by two women, Khaleda Zia and Sheikh Hasina. For 10 points, name this South Asian country whose capital is Dhaka.
tossups.answer: People’s Republic of Bangladesh [or Gônoprojatontri Bangladesh] <Modern World>

tossups.question: Donald Matteson’s group homologated compounds containing this hetero·atom using alpha-halogenated organo·lithium reagents like di·chloro·methyl·lithium. This heteroatom forms a high-temperature ferromagnet with calcium, and a similar compound it forms with lanthanum has a very low work function; in both of those compounds, this atom is found in an octahedral polyatomic ion with minus-2 charge. It can form organic derivatives for chemical synthesis by reaction with alpha-pinene or (*) pinacol. A magnesium compound with two of this atom in its formula unit is a type I superconductor at 30 Kelvin. A D2h compound containing this heteroatom can be described by a combination of two separate M·O diagrams, one of which has contributions of a B3u and an A·g set from its two central hydrogen atoms. Eleven of this atom bond to a carbon atom and eleven halogen atoms to form a superacid. For 10 points, name this element that forms three-center two-electron bonds in its compounds with hydrogen.
tossups.answer: boron [or B] <Science - Chemistry>

tossups.question: This artist inspired Rosalind Krauss’s essay on “The Aesthetics of Narcissism” with a video piece that shows this artist kissing a video-within-a-video double and asking that double the title question: “Now?” This sculptor recast an earlier work in lead to create the piece Quartered Meteor. This artist used lightweight metals like aluminum to make knot-shaped pieces like Eridanus and the glitter-sprinkled sculpture Psi. This artist’s early works of the mid-1960s include a series of layered, lozenge-shaped (*) wax sculptures to be hung like paintings. This artist poured paint directly onto the floor to create sculptures like Fallen Painting. In 1974, this artist ran an infamous ad in Artforum depicting herself wearing only sunglasses and using a double-ended dildo. For 10 points, name this contemporary feminist artist known for her latex sculptures.
tossups.answer: Lynda Benglis <Arts - Visual>

tossups.question: The “absolute” version of this idea was called a “specious present” by a philosopher who claimed that this idea could only exist in isolation through “pure esthesis,” and called this idea “thin” by contrast with “the thick experience of the world of things.” A paper attacking this idea includes a thought experiment about a man who encounters deceptive colors for the first time in a necktie shop, demonstrating that “being so” is logically prior to “looking so.” This idea as an (*) “element in experience” titles the second chapter of C. I. Lewis’s Mind and the World Order. Another philosopher responded to Mind and the World Order with a paper that begins by referring to this idea as a “piece of epistemological shoptalk.” This idea was opposed to the “myth of Jones” in “Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind.” For 10 points, name this idea that Wilfrid Sellars attacked as a “myth.”
tossups.answer: Myth of the Given [or givenness, given in experience, and word forms of “given”; prompt on sense-data, perception, or experience] <Philosophy>

tossups.question: Matthew Delmon’s 2016 book on “why [this policy] failed” blamed inaccurate media narratives, citing incidents like a 600-mile women’s march by Irene McCabe and the National Action Group, who punned on their extremely appropriate acronym to oppose this policy with the chant “NAG, NAG, NAG.” The relatively inexperienced Julius Chambers argued the case establishing this policy, which saw six wildly varying drafts circulated as justices sought a unanimous decision. After a later case, Morgan v. Hennigan, the group (*) Restore Our Alienated Rights, or ROAR, formed to oppose this policy in Boston, where Joseph Rakes was photographed attacking Ted Landsmark with an American Flag during a namesake “crisis.” Tthis policy was mandated in the case Swann v. Charlotte-Mecklenburg. For 10 points, name this policy aimed at carrying out 1954’s Brown v. Board of Ed ruling, which sought to facilitate desegregation by transporting students to different schools on the namesake vehicles.
tossups.answer: busing [prompt on desegregation; continue to prompt on more specific answers like integrating schools, etc.] <History - American>

tossups.question: At the 2018 Wheaton Conference, this thinker and former Archbishop of Canterbury Rowan Williams held a dialogue about the importance of “imagination” and “the ordinary” in faith. This author recalled the childhood impact of religious prose in an essay on Psalm 8 collected in the volume The Death of Adam. This thinker called democracy “the inevitable consequence of…religious humanism” in a mammoth, two-part 2015 New York Review of Books interview with Barack (*) Obama. This author continued a longstanding attack on neo-Darwinist atheism and a defence of Calvinist theology in the 2015 collection The Givenness of Things. This thinker put many of her Congregationalist theological ideas into a fictional letter written by Iowan preacher John Ames. For 10 points, name this author who has developed her theology in novels like Housekeeping and Gilead.
tossups.answer: Marilynne Robinson <Religion>

tossups.question: A Bob Kaufman poem whose title ends with this word declares “the radio is teaching my goldfish jujitsu” and “Consolidated Edison is threatening to cut off my brain.” This is the final word in the title of a Nikki Giovanni poem whose narrator resolves to use her credit card to get “everything in town” after being left alone on Wednesday night. Those examples of this genre are named “Heavy Water” and “Master Charge.” This genre typically uses an (*) AAB stanza, where A is the “repeat line” and B is the “response line.” A review by Ralph Ellison attacks the “tremendous burden of sociology” put on this title genre in a 1963 book by Amiri Baraka. Robert Hayden wrote a “homage” to the “empress” of this genre, which titles a poem depicting a man “swaying to and fro on his rickety stool” and playing this type of song “like a musical fool” on Lenox Avenue. For 10 points, name this genre of music that a Langston Hughes title describes as “weary.”
tossups.answer: the blues [accept Blues People] <Literature - American>

tossups.question: The second chapter of a book from this dynasty opens with the narrator describing his childhood ability to stare directly at the sun, and then recounting how he was stung by a worm while masturbating. In that book from this dynasty, the narrator’s wife brings in a mistress ostensibly “for her husband,” but later becomes despondent and dies after that mistress is stolen by a wealthy man. In a story from this dynasty, a scholar’s heart is ripped out by the (*) “painted-skin” demon Huàpí. A memoir from this dynasty was rediscovered 70 years after its completion, but only four of its title number of chapters survive. A historical narrative from this dynasty was interwoven with short stories from it in The Death of Woman Wang by Jonathan Spence. Shěn Fù [shun FOO] and Pú Sōnglíng wrote Six Records of a Floating Life and Strange Tales from a Chinese Studio during—for 10 points—what dynasty in which Cáo Xuěqín [tsao shyoo-eh cheen] wrote Dream of the Red Chamber?
tossups.answer: Qíng [cheeng] dynasty [do not accept or prompt on “Qín”] <Literature - Other/World>

tossups.question: One kind of artwork made of this material was often decorated with the geometric “box and border” motif. Styles of painting on this material were adapted into the later tradition of “ledger art.” This material was once used to make illustrated calendars called “winter counts.” Traditionally, narrative painting on this material was made by men, while women used it to make geometrically-decorated parfleches. Clothes made mainly of this material are worn by the subjects of the most famous paintings by Karl Bodmer and George Catlin. This material was once painted with scenes of battle or hunting before being draped over (*) lodgepoles. Works in this material are frequently decorated with quillwork and beads. This material was usually used to make the band or cap decorated with eagle feathers to make a war bonnet. For 10 points, name this material traditionally used to make moccasins and cover tipis.
tossups.answer: rawhide [accept leather; accept more specific answers like buffalo hides or deer hides; accept buffalo skins] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>

tossups.question: A British convoy moving through this conflict was fired on by friendly troops who could only see the red lines on the Union Jack, which they assumed to be the banner of some especially crazy socialists. Journalist August Wesley left Duluth to become a commander in this conflict. This war did not involve kaiju, but one side made extensive use of veterans from the earlier Jäger Program. Veterans of this conflict launched the Aunus and Vien as part of the (*) “Kinship Wars” in nearby countries. Ethnic cleansing in this war included the Vyborg Massacre, perpetrated by Martin Ekstrom’s Vaasa regiment, which had been sent by a neighboring power. The Battle of Tampere occurred during this war, fought at the same time as larger conflict to the east that also pitted Reds against Whites. Ali Aaltonen was defeated by Carl Mannerheim in—for 10 points—what 1918 civil war that ended with the establishment of a new government at Helsinki?
tossups.answer: Finnish Civil War [prompt on Russian Civil War ONLY during the first sentence; do not accept afterward; definitely do not accept “the Winter War” or “Continuation War”] <History - Mediterranean+>

tossups.question: One essay uses the example of this country owing interest on an IDB loan it never received as an example of “structural violence.” In this country, the disease of move san [moh-veh SAH], or bad blood, is seen as causing rural mothers to provide bad milk in so-called lèt gate [lay gah-TAY] syndrome. One thinker described how “water refugees” in this country’s pseudonymous village of Do Kay variously attributed the spread of (*) sida on jealousy, conspiracy, and traveling to this country’s capital city. A book whose subtitle pairs this country with the “geography of blame” refutes the widespread idea that AIDS traveled to the U.S. from this country. Much of the medical anthropologist Paul Farmer’s research focuses on disease in—for 10 points—what Caribbean country, whose sick citizens in search of traditional healing sometimes turn to houngans and mambos?
tossups.answer: Republic of Haiti [or République d’Haïti or Repiblik Ayiti] <Social Science>

tossups.question: These functions can be uniquely written as the difference of two-positive valued examples of them, using the Hahn and Jordan decomposition theorems. The existence of a unique one of these functions is guaranteed in order to allow the representation of positive linear functionals by one of the Riesz Representation Theorems. The domain of these functions must always include sets of the type “G-delta” and “F-sigma.” Iterated functions that leave this kind of function invariant are the subject of the Poincaré Recurrence Theorem. The set of representatives of (*) R-quotient-Q in the unit interval does not fall within the domain of one of these functions, by a theorem of Vitali. One of these functions that takes values between 0 and 1 and has a value of 1 for the entire sample space is often used in general probability theory. These functions are defined over sigma-algebras. For 10 points, name these functions used to define the Lebesgue integral.
tossups.answer: measures [accept more specific answers like Lebesgue measures] <Science - Other>   Chicago Open 2019: What If We Kissed 😳 in the Non-Western Art Distribution 😳  Edited by Chris Ray, Jacob Reed, Alston Boyd, Will Holub-Moorman, Jonathan Magin, and Sriram Pendyala, with contributions by Wonyoung Jang and Michael Kearney.  Packet by the Editors (1)  Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: In this dialogue, one debater cited Adriaan van Maanen’s claim to measure the period of rotation of the Pinwheel galaxy as 100,000 years. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this “Great Debate” between two namesake astronomers, which concerned the nature of spiral nebulae and the size of the universe.
Curtis used this term, coined by Immanuel Kant, to describe nebulae. This term was later replaced by the term “galaxy.”

Before the debates, Curtis gathered evidence for his “island universes” hypothesis for two decades at this first permanent mountaintop observatory in the world. A.A. Michelson measured the diameter of Jupiter’s moons at this observatory on the summit of Mount Hamilton in Santa Clara County.

bonuses.leadin: These events were revealed in a tearful confession in front of the Council of Piacenza. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Holy Roman Emperor Henry IV’s satanic orgies [accept answers involving Henry IV doing anything kinky or satan-y, particular answers involving a black mass]
Gregory VII [or Hildebrand of Sovana; prompt on Gregory or Hildebrand]
Matilda of Tuscany [or Matilde di Canossa] <History - European>
parts: Describe these events, which some chroniclers blamed on the perpetrator’s secret adherence to Nicolaism. These events reportedly culminated in Conrad II’s rebellion after he refused his father’s attempts to get him to rape the half-sister of Vladimir II Monomakh.

The charge that Henry had forced Eupraxia of Kiev to engage in satanic orgies was popularized by Urban II, the successor of this pope, who forced Henry to beg for forgiveness in the snow outside Canossa.
Canossa was controlled by this major rival of Henry, who was known as “La Gran Contessa.” This woman’s power was cemented after her husband, Godfrey the Hunchback, was speared to death while pooping.

bonuses.leadin: Susan Gal studied this process in the Austrian town of Oberwart, and a book titled for “reversing” it via an eight-stage “revival” process was written by Joshua Fishman. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: language shift [or language transfer, or language replacement; also accept Reversing Language Shift; prompt on language death; do not accept “language change,” as that refers to change within a certain language]
Scotland [or Alba] (Dorian studied Scottish Gaelic; the other language is Scots.) <Social Science>
parts: Name this process that can occur over time as populations abandon systems described by scholars as “heritage” in favor of ones labeled as “prestige.”

After most of this Polynesian language’s speakers shifted to English during the twentieth century, recent attempts to revive it have involved placing children in immersive “language nests,” or kōhanga reo, in cities like Dunedin.

Nancy Dorian’s concept of “speaker types” for a dying language grew out of her work on a dialect from this country. A different language in this modern-day country has a “Doric” dialect traditionally spoken in its northeast.

bonuses.leadin: The Natya Shastra lists eight types of this concept, which is used to express bhavas. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: eyeliner [prompt on makeup or cosmetics; do not accept or prompt on “eye shadow”] <Arts - Audiovisual, Other>
parts: Name this core concept of Indian aesthetics, which refers to the emotional essence of an artwork or performance.

The nine rasas are expressed using gestures and facial expressions by performers in bharata·natyam and other Indian varieties of this general art form. Actors wearing colorful costumes perform this art form to the music of three kinds of drum in the dramatic form of kathakali.

Performers in several types of Indian classical dance typically use kohl as one of these substances. These substances are often used to create a “winged” appearance, and are sometimes used “tight” against the waterline.

bonuses.leadin: In a poem by Rafael Obligado, one of these people is defeated by Juan Sin Ropa, who is really the Devil in disguise. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: payadas [or singing contests; or singing duels; accept any answer that indicates people competing through songs or verses]
parts: Name this type of person, who was idealized as a national hero thanks to a series of 1913 lectures by Leopoldo Lugones. Lugones especially praised the depiction of these people in the José Hernández poem Martín Fierro.

Gaucho literature often depicts these events, in which two gauchos improvise ways to one-up one another. Martín Fierro ends with one of these events involving the title character and an unnamed black man. A description is fine.
In a mock epic written by Estanislao del Campo, a gaucho named Pollo runs into his friend Laguna in Buenos Aires, and recounts a performance of this opera as though its events were real.

bonuses.leadin: Bodean Gazzer and his sidekick Chub steal a winning lottery ticket from JoLayne Lucks to fund their underground militia in this author’s novel Lucky You. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Carl Hiaasen (Yes, the writer of Hoot.)
parts: Name this contemporary American author, whose many satirical crime novels include Sick Puppy, Skinny Dip, and Nature Girl.
Hiaasen’s novels chronicle the seedy side of this state. A family of alligator wrestlers lives off the coast of this state in Karen Russell’s novel Swamplandia!
Bob Dubois and Vanise Dorsinville are tragically drawn to Florida in this author’s novel Continental Drift. He depicted the aftermath of a deadly school bus accident in his novel The Sweet Hereafter.

bonuses.leadin: This idea was promoted by the Southern School in a move away from the Lankāvatāra Sutra. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: sudden enlightenment [or sudden awakening; accept subitism; prompt on partial answer; prompt on bodhi or satori or kenshō]
Heart Sutra [or Prajñāpāramitāhrdayam; or Xīnjīng [sheen jeeng]; or “Hs’in-ching”] <Religion>
parts: Name this belief that the Platform Sutra illustrates with a story about Huìnéng [HWAY-nung] hearing a recitation of the Diamond Sutra.

This state is what Chán Buddhists typically claim is attained in sudden enlightenment. Texts like the Diamond Sutra are grouped together for their focus on this kind of insight into shunyata or “emptiness.”

The “Perfection of prajñā,” or prajñāpāramitā genre is also exemplified by this sutra, which is short enough that Yáng Guìfēi [yahng gway-FAY] was supposedly able to teach it to her parrot. This sutra expresses the doctrine of Two Truths with the declaration “Form is empty” and purports to be the namesake body part of prajñāpāramitā.

bonuses.leadin: A company controlled by this man expanded in the wake of the Treaty of Fort Bridger. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: she saved her brother [accept equivalents; accept The Battle Where the Girl Saved Her Brother] <History - American>
parts: Name this prolific Gilded Age robber baron who tried to use Abel Corbin to influence the Grant administration while he and James Fisk tried to corner the gold market, triggering Black Friday.
The Treaty of Fort Bridger was signed in 1878 with this Native American tribe. This tribe’s leaders included Pocatello.

The Shoshone were present at the Battle of the Rosebud during the Great Sioux War, where Indian forces were rallied to victory after Buffalo Calf Road Woman took this famous action, which provides an alternate name for the battle.

bonuses.leadin: A feminist critique of this concept argues that the requirement of “internal liberalism” gives this concept a much smaller scope than generally thought. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this concept. Liberal defenders of this concept such as Will Kymlicka often ground their support on a theory of “group rights,” while postcolonial defenders reject the universality of liberal norms.

This philosopher wrote the aforementioned “Is Multiculturalism Bad For Women?” She is best-known for articulating a feminist critique and expansion of liberalism in the book Justice, Gender, and the Family.
Okin is most famous for providing a feminist critique of this philosopher. This liberal political philosopher tried to argue for egalitarian politics with his “original position” thought experiment.

bonuses.leadin: This theorist illustrated the dictum “The meaning of the work emerges from the interplay of activating and balancing forces” with an analysis of the lines structuring the portrait Madame Cézanne in a Yellow Chair. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this art theorist who used Gestalt psychology as the basis for his landmark 1954 book Art and Visual Perception.

Arnheim’s theory of pictorial resemblance is often contrasted with the theory of artistic representation in this art historian’s 1960 book Art and Illusion. His works include The Sense of Order and “Meditations on a Hobby-Horse.”

Arnheim sought to demonstrate his theories on “visual thinking” in a book on the Genesis of this painting. This monochrome 1937 painting depicts a horse with a knife-like tongue amid a group of wailing women.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about stereoelectronic effects that stabilize particular geometries, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: electron-withdrawing group [or EWG; prompt on polar or electronegative]
parts: First, name this effect that stabilizes the beta-conformation of pyranose sugars over the alpha-conformation. It is due to donation from the oxygen nonbonding pair into the carbon-hydroxyl bond sigma-star orbital.

In the Felkin–Anh model, putting a substituent with this property onto the alpha-carbon results in anti-Felkin selectivity. Putting a substituent with this property on the dienophile accelerates a Diels–Alder reaction.

Both the Felkin–Anh model and the anomeric effect involve hyperconjugation, which can be represented as a “no-bond” form of one of these structures. The nitrate ion has three of these contributing structures, which are combined in Lewis theory to give an electron-delocalized picture of a molecule.

bonuses.leadin: This label attracted controversy for its use of eccentric shoes like the mink-lined Birkenstock-style sandals in its Spring 2013 show. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy [or LVMH] <Modern World>
parts: Name this brand that became known for minimal, restrained lines under creative director Phoebe Philo, who left in 2018.

Céline is now led by Philo’s polar opposite, i.e. this punk-inspired designer with Tunisian heritage. He was creative director at Dior Homme in the early 2000s and then led Yves Saint Laurent until 2016.

Both Dior and Céline, as well as Fendi and Marc Jacobs, are owned by this huge French luxury goods conglomerate. Its namesake fashion house is known for its oft-ripped-off, checkerboard-patterned “Speedy” bag.

bonuses.leadin: Francisque Michel interpreted this word as a sort of battle cry. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Mont Saint Michel and Chartres <Literature - European>
parts: Name this mysterious three-letter word that appears after many stanzas in The Song of Roland.

The 81st of these poems exclaims “AOI!” before declaring “What thou lovest well remains / The rest is dross.” That poem is part of a group of them written in 1945 while their author was imprisoned near Pisa.

The second chapter of this other book links the masculinity of The Song of Roland with Romanesque architecture. Many of its later chapters analyze how Gothic architecture arose from the intense devotion to the Virgin Mary in twelfth- and thirteenth-century France.

bonuses.leadin: This man first came to prominence playing with Jaco Pastorius in Joni Mitchell’s band of the early ‘70s. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Antônio Carlos (Brasileiro de Almeida) Jobim <Arts - Auditory>
parts: Name this guitarist whose “group” has released hit jazz fusion albums like Offramp. His request for a guitar with “as many strings as possible” resulted in the 42-string Pikasso.

In his early work, Metheny often played parallel lines this interval apart. Normally, all but one of the guitar’s strings are tuned this interval from their lower neighbor, and it’s the interval between C and F.
Metheny’s longtime collaboration with Brazilian musicians has included playing with this pianist, who wrote “Desafinado” and “The Girl from Ipanema.”

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions about the work of a physicist who computed of the yield of a nuclear bomb using dimensional analysis and published his result in Life magazine in 1953—for 10 points each:
parts: First, name this theorem that states that the frictionless flow of a barotropic and incompressible fluid being steadily rotated is entirely two-dimensional. Its consequence is that an obstacle in a small region of the flow will cause deflection of an entire column of that flow.

The Taylor–Proudman theorem is useful for describing geophysical phenomena, but only holds when this number is small. This is the ratio of inertial forces to Coriolis forces, and it’s small under the approximation of geostrophic balance when Coriolis and pressure gradient forces are equal.

G.I. Taylor also names an instability with Rayleigh that grows at interfaces between two fluids with different values for this property. Osmium is the metallic element with the highest value for this property.

bonuses.leadin: The development of agglomerated urban settlements in Mesopotamia occurred during this city’s eponymous period, which lasted for the majority of the fourth millennium B.C. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: Uruk [or Erech; or Unug; or Orchoe; or Orchoi; do not accept or prompt on “Ur”]
Sargon of Akkad [or Sargon I; or Sargon the Great] <History - Mediterranean+>
parts: Name this Mesopotamian city, whose main place of worship has been termed the “White Temple” due to its gypsum coating. This city was divided into two districts, the “Eanna” district and the “Anu” district.

The period of Mesopotamian history preceding that of Uruk is named for this site, which was partly excavated by Leonard Woolley. This site also names a prominent “black-on-buff pottery” style found throughout Mesopotamia.

Eventually this ruler conquered Uruk, placing his daughter, Enheduanna, as the part-time custodian of the city’s cult to Ishtar. According to the Sumerian King List, this ruler once served as cup-bearer to Ur-Zababa, king of Kish.

bonuses.leadin: One of these places corrupts the title character of Frederic W. Farrar’s Victorian novel Eric, or Little by Little. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: boarding schools [do not accept colleges or universities]
parts: Name this type of location often used as a setting by Talbot Baines Reed. A more popular Victorian novel is set at one of these places run by Dr. Thomas Arnold.
The protagonist of this Charlotte Bronte novel attends Lowood, a boarding school where she is cruelly mistreated by Mr. Brocklehurst.

This children’s author wrote a series of novels set at the fictitious boarding school Malory Towers. She also created the fictional village of Toyland, populated by characters like Big Ears and the policeman Mr. Plod.

bonuses.leadin: The destruction of ventilation systems by this man’s forces created a still-extant terrifying highway of death, where dust sometimes drops visibility to zero in the Salang Tunnel. For 10 points each:
answers_sanitized: rockets [prompt on general answers involving artillery or missile; accept more specific answers like Qassam rockets] <History - Other/World>
parts: Identify this leader of Northern Alliance, an Afghan warlord who defended Kabul from a Taliban siege and was assassinated just days before September 11, 2001.

Sympathetic agents warned Massoud to expect a ceasefire with the USSR to be broken following this man’s death, leading to high Russian casualties. This man was succeeded as head of the USSR by Konstantin Chernenko.

This sort of weapon was the primary tool used during the extended siege of Kabul during the 1990’s. More notable examples of these weapons from a different conflict are often named after Izz ad-Din al-Qassam.

bonuses.leadin: When insulin binds to its receptor’s extracellular domain on hepatocytes, the receptor dimerizes. Answer the following about that process, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: protein kinase B [or PKB; or Akt]
parts: The intracellular domain of the dimerized receptor undergoes auto·phosphoryl·ation on this protein residue. Human kinases most commonly phosphorylate this aromatic amino acid.

Phosphorylated beta-subunits of the insulin receptor leads to activation of PI3 kinase via the insulin receptor substrate. PIP3 then diffuses to bind the pleckstrin homology domain of this serine / threonine kinase, leading to its activation and downstream mTORC signal integration.

Insulin signaling leads to downregulation of a kinase activated by this molecule; that kinase is instead active when cellular energy levels are low. This molecule is a potent allosteric activator of the rate-limiting glycolytic enzyme phospho·fructo·kinase-1.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about letters that gradually fell out of use in their original languages, for 10 points each.
answers_sanitized: edh [or eth] and thorn <Mythology and Other>
parts: This archaic Greek letter, which denoted the sound /w/ [wuh], had vanished by Homer’s time. The former presence of this F-shaped letter can, however, be inferred from some Homeric lines that would otherwise be metrically inaccurate.

The letters for three of the four “syllabic consonants,” an important feature of this language, are no longer used in the Devanagari script. That script, first used to write this language, is still in use among many of its daughter languages, such as Marathi.

Old and Middle English contained a number of letters that are no longer in use. Among them is the ligature Æ [A-E], also known as “ash,” and two letters that both correspond to Modern English “th.” Give the name for both.
